content.text: What's terminal ANSI code to print a hyperlink?

outputs.text:
Terminal ANSI code (also known as "ANSI X3.2-1983", also referred to as "ANSI 000") for printing a hyperlink is:

- Escape sequence: `\e[4m` (or `\E[4m`)
- The `m` escape code means "inverted video mode" or "background", which makes the text appear black on white.
- To make this hyperlink appear underlined and in bold, append an additional underscore "_": `\e[4m_` (or `\E[4m_`).

Example:

```bash
$ echo -e "\e[01;31mHyperlink to www.google.com!\e[0m"
   ________________________    
  |                         |
  |       www.google.com    |
  |_________________________|
    ^^^^^^               ^^^^^^
```

Example:

```bash

```

1. `0x07`: ASCII 0 (black on black)
2. `0x1b`: ASCII 3 (reverse video)
3. `0x5b`: ASCII 96 (beginning of horizontal attribute section)
4. `0x5c`: ASCII 97 (beginning of vertical attribute section)

Here's an example to set the black background and text color to red on a green terminal:

```shell
echo -e "\e[1;31mhello\e[m"
```

Output:

```
hello 
```

With these terminal ANSI codes, you can make the terminal display an underlined black text (on top of the red background) on a green background.

What's VT100 code to print a hyperlink?

outputs.text:
Sure, here's an example VT100 code to print a hyperlink using the `printf()` function:

```
printf("[hyperlink] Click here to go to website! [/hyperlink]\n");
```

In this example, `[hyperlink]` is the target of the hyperlink and `[/hyperlink]` is the anchor (the text that appears next to the hyperlink). `%s` stands for "string," which can be used to insert a user-defined string as a link. For example: `printf("[user-defined link] Go to %s! [/user-defined link]\n", "website URL")` will display "Click here to go to website! Go to www.example.com." This technique is commonly used in web development to create hyperlinks that navigate users to other pages or resources on a webpage.

What's terminal ANSI code to print a hyperlink?

outputs.text:
Terminal ANSI code (also known as "ANSI X3.2-1983", also referred to as "ANSI 000") for printing a hyperlink is:

- Escape sequence: `\e[4m` (or `\E[4m`)
- The `m` escape code means "inverted video mode" or "background", which makes the text appear black on white.
- To make this hyperlink appear underlined and in bold, append an additional underscore "_": `\e[4m_` (or `\E[4m_`).

Example:

```bash
$ echo -e "\e[01;31mHyperlink to www.google.com!\e[0m"
   ________________________    
  |                         |
  |       www.google.com    |
  |_________________________|
    ^^^^^^               ^^^^^^
```

content.text: What's terminal ANSI code to print a hyperlink?

Terminal ANSI code (also known as "ANSI X3.2-1983", also referred to as "ANSI 000") for printing a hyperlink is:

- Escape sequence: `\e[4m` (or `\E[4m`)
- The `m` escape code means "inverted video mode" or "background", which makes the text appear black on white.
- To make this hyperlink appear underlined and in bold, append an additional underscore "_": `\e[4m_` (or `\E[4m_`).

Example:

```bash
$ echo -e "\e[01;31mHyperlink to www.google.com!\e[0m"
   ________________________    
  |                         |
  |       www.google.com    |
  |_________________________|
    ^^^^^^               ^^^^^^
```

2. `0x1b`: ASCII 3 (reverse video)
3. `0x5b`: ASCII 96 (beginning of horizontal attribute section)
4. `0x5c`: ASCII 97 (beginning of vertical attribute section)

Here's an example to set the black background and text color to red on a green terminal:

```shell
echo -e "\e[1;31mhello\e[m"
```

hello 
```

```
printf("[hyperlink] Click here to go to website! [/hyperlink]\n");

outputs.text:
To make the terminal bell (or sound) start or stop, you can use one of two ASCII codes:
- `^M` (terminal ANSI mode 100): This stands for "ASCII mode 100." It means that the terminal is in "ANSI" mode.
- `\a(`: This stands for "bell" or "system sound". It means that the bell (or other sound) is set to start ringing at the current terminal mode, as specified by `^M`.

Here's an example:
```bash
# Set the terminal bell to start ringing in ANSI mode 100 and at a volume of 95%
echo -n "\a(95%" | terminal
```
This will make the terminal bell start ringing, with a volume of 95% in ANSI mode 100.

The bell (also known as the "pager bell") is often used with OSC 8 to indicate when new text has been displayed on the terminal. When the terminal receives an OSC 8 command, the system will play a series of short beeps in succession until the user presses a key or the cursor moves onto a different line. This behavior allows users to quickly scan through output and see what changes have occurred without having to navigate away from the current window or use the "back" arrow to scroll back up.

Here is an example of how to use the "repeaat archive" functionality in your bash script to extract the contents and attributes of a specific file:

```bash
#!/bin/sh

repaeat -f demo.rar -a .* -l "notvirus.*$" | while read -r filename
do
    echo "Extracting $filename..."
    # Extract the contents and attributes of the extracted file
    echo "$filename" >> out.txt
done
```

In this example, we are using the `repaeat` command to extract the contents and attributes of files inside the `demo.rar` archive. We're passing two options (`-a .*`, which matches any filename ending with `.*` (i.e., any file), and `-l "notvirus.*$"`, which matches files that contain a string starting with `"notvirus"` followed by a dollar sign ("$").

Once the extracted files have been saved to `out.txt`, we can open it for inspection or do whatever other operations you might want to perform on the extracted content.

outputs.text:
\u001b[ is a control sequence used in terminal emulation software such as Windows PowerShell or Git Bash, which sets the color and attributes of the displayed text. The \u001b[] notation means "set attribute", and [] refers to the background (color) and foreground (text) properties respectively. The following raw bytes encode the \u001b[ command with a 256-byte sequence:

- The first four bytes represent the ASCII code for the ESC character, which is represented by the hexadecimal number "\\" ("\\" in binary = 101).
- The next two bytes are zeroes.
- The following five bytes indicate the first byte of the \u001b[ command, which is the ASCII code for the BACKSPACE character (ASCII code 0x08), represented by the hexadecimal number "\\\08" ("\\\08 in binary = 127")
- The next two bytes represent the second byte of the \u001b[ command, which is the ASCII code for color mode (the character "+" represents bright), represented by the hexadecimal number "\\\+43" ("\\\+43 in binary = 57")
- The next four bytes represent the second byte of the \u001b[ command, which is the ASCII code for text mode (the character "-" represents dark), represented by the hexadecimal number "\\\-59" ("\\\-59 in binary = 81")
- The last two bytes are zeroes.

In this example, the raw bytes sequence would look like: 

001b[ 
   +43++59 
      +81

What's terminal ANSI code to make the terminal bell ding?

outputs.text:
To make the terminal bell (or sound) start or stop, you can use one of two ASCII codes:
- `^M` (terminal ANSI mode 100): This stands for "ASCII mode 100." It means that the terminal is in "ANSI" mode.
- `\a(`: This stands for "bell" or "system sound". It means that the bell (or other sound) is set to start ringing at the current terminal mode, as specified by `^M`.

Here's an example:
```bash
# Set the terminal bell to start ringing in ANSI mode 100 and at a volume of 95%
echo -n "\a(95%" | terminal
```
This will make the terminal bell start ringing, with a volume of 95% in ANSI mode 100.

Here is an example of how to use the "repeaat archive" functionality in your bash script to extract the contents and attributes of a specific file:

```bash
#!/bin/sh

repaeat -f demo.rar -a .* -l "notvirus.*$" | while read -r filename
do
    echo "Extracting $filename..."
    # Extract the contents and attributes of the extracted file
    echo "$filename" >> out.txt
done
```

In this example, we are using the `repaeat` command to extract the contents and attributes of files inside the `demo.rar` archive. We're passing two options (`-a .*`, which matches any filename ending with `.*` (i.e., any file), and `-l "notvirus.*$"`, which matches files that contain a string starting with `"notvirus"` followed by a dollar sign ("$").

Once the extracted files have been saved to `out.txt`, we can open it for inspection or do whatever other operations you might want to perform on the extracted content.

outputs.text:
\u001b[ is a control sequence used in terminal emulation software such as Windows PowerShell or Git Bash, which sets the color and attributes of the displayed text. The \u001b[] notation means "set attribute", and [] refers to the background (color) and foreground (text) properties respectively. The following raw bytes encode the \u001b[ command with a 256-byte sequence:

- The first four bytes represent the ASCII code for the ESC character, which is represented by the hexadecimal number "\\" ("\\" in binary = 101).
- The next two bytes are zeroes.
- The following five bytes indicate the first byte of the \u001b[ command, which is the ASCII code for the BACKSPACE character (ASCII code 0x08), represented by the hexadecimal number "\\\08" ("\\\08 in binary = 127")
- The next two bytes represent the second byte of the \u001b[ command, which is the ASCII code for color mode (the character "+" represents bright), represented by the hexadecimal number "\\\+43" ("\\\+43 in binary = 57")
- The next four bytes represent the second byte of the \u001b[ command, which is the ASCII code for text mode (the character "-" represents dark), represented by the hexadecimal number "\\\-59" ("\\\-59 in binary = 81")
- The last two bytes are zeroes.

In this example, the raw bytes sequence would look like: 

001b[ 
   +43++59 
      +81
